questions.question: The subsequent event period ends when:

options.B: Financial statements are issued or available to be issued

questions.explanation: The subsequent event period extends from the balance sheet date until the financial statements are issued (SEC filers) or available to be issued (non-SEC filers).
questions.tip: Subsequent event period: balance sheet date â†’ issuance date.

questions.question: The two types of subsequent events are:

options.B: Recognized and nonrecognized

questions.explanation: Subsequent events are classified as recognized (Type 1) events that provide additional evidence about conditions at the balance sheet date, or nonrecognized (Type 2) events that arise after the balance sheet date.
questions.tip: Type 1: recognized (adjust). Type 2: nonrecognized (disclose).

questions.question: Which is an example of a recognized (Type 1) subsequent event?

options.A: Declaration of a stock split after year-end
options.B: Settlement of litigation after year-end for an amount different than accrued, involving events that occurred before year-end
options.C: Loss of a major customer after year-end

questions.explanation: The litigation settlement provides additional evidence about a condition (the lawsuit) that existed at year-end. The financial statements should be adjusted to reflect the settlement amount.
questions.tip: Type 1: provides evidence about year-end conditions.

questions.question: Which is an example of a nonrecognized (Type 2) subsequent event?

options.A: Collection of a receivable written off before year-end
options.B: A fire that destroys a major plant after year-end
options.C: Bankruptcy of a customer whose balance was outstanding at year-end
options.D: Discovery of fraud that occurred before year-end

questions.explanation: The fire is a new event arising after year-end that doesn't provide evidence about conditions existing at year-end. It's disclosed but doesn't adjust the financial statements.
questions.tip: Type 2: new event after year-end = disclose only.

questions.question: A recognized subsequent event requires:

options.B: Adjustment of the financial statements

questions.explanation: Recognized (Type 1) subsequent events require adjustment of the financial statements to reflect the additional evidence about conditions that existed at the balance sheet date.
questions.tip: Recognized = adjust financial statements.

questions.question: Nonrecognized subsequent events that would affect users' understanding require disclosure of:

options.A: Only the nature of the event
options.B: The nature of the event and an estimate of its financial effect (or statement that estimate cannot be made)

questions.explanation: For material nonrecognized subsequent events, disclosure should include the nature of the event and an estimate of its financial effect, or a statement that such estimate cannot be made.
questions.tip: Type 2 disclosure: nature + estimated financial effect.

questions.question: When financial statements are reissued, the entity should evaluate subsequent events through:

options.B: The reissuance date

questions.explanation: For reissued financial statements, subsequent events are evaluated through the new reissuance date. However, the evaluation is limited to the specific matter being revised.
questions.tip: Reissuance: evaluate subsequent events through new date.

questions.question: A loss contingency is:

options.B: An existing condition involving uncertainty about possible loss depending on future events

questions.explanation: A loss contingency is an existing condition, situation, or set of circumstances involving uncertainty as to possible loss that will be resolved when future events occur or fail to occur.
questions.tip: Contingency = existing uncertainty about possible future loss.

questions.question: A loss contingency is accrued when:

options.B: The loss is probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated

questions.explanation: Under ASC 450, a loss contingency is accrued when: (1) it is probable that a loss has been incurred, and (2) the amount can be reasonably estimated.
questions.tip: Accrue loss: probable + reasonably estimable.

questions.question: If a loss is 'reasonably possible' but not 'probable,' the entity should:

options.B: Disclose the nature and estimate of possible loss (or range)

questions.explanation: When a loss is reasonably possible (more than remote but less than probable), disclosure is required but accrual is not. Disclosure includes the nature of the contingency and estimate of possible loss.
questions.tip: Reasonably possible = disclose only, don't accrue.

questions.question: If a loss contingency is considered 'remote,' the entity should:

options.B: Disclose the loss

questions.explanation: Remote loss contingencies generally require no accrual or disclosure. However, certain guarantees must be disclosed regardless of probability.
questions.tip: Remote = generally no accrual, no disclosure.

questions.question: When a range of loss exists for a probable loss contingency and no amount in the range is a better estimate:

options.B: The minimum (low end) of the range is accrued

questions.explanation: When a range of loss is probable and no single amount is the best estimate, the minimum amount in the range is accrued. The additional exposure above the minimum is disclosed.
questions.tip: Range with no best estimate: accrue the minimum.

questions.question: Gain contingencies are:

options.B: Not recognized until realized; may be disclosed if probable

questions.explanation: Gain contingencies are not recognized until realized (conservatism). Adequate disclosure should be made, but care should be taken to avoid misleading implications about the likelihood of realization.
questions.tip: Gain contingency: don't recognize until realized.

questions.question: A company is being sued for $500,000. Legal counsel believes an unfavorable outcome is probable and estimates the loss at $300,000-$400,000. The company should:

options.B: Accrue $300,000 and disclose the range

questions.explanation: With a range where no amount is the best estimate, accrue the minimum ($300,000). Disclose that the actual loss could be up to $400,000.
questions.tip: Probable loss with range: accrue minimum, disclose range.

questions.question: Product warranty costs should be:

options.A: Expensed when warranty claims are paid
options.B: Accrued at the time of sale based on estimated future warranty costs

questions.explanation: Warranty costs meet the criteria for accrual: the loss is probable (some products will fail) and estimable (based on historical data). Expense is matched to the period of sale.
questions.tip: Warranties: accrue at time of sale (matching principle).

questions.question: An environmental remediation liability should be recognized when:

options.B: Litigation has been commenced by the EPA and the entity is named as a potentially responsible party, making an obligation probable and estimable

questions.explanation: Environmental liabilities are recognized when it's probable an obligation has been incurred and the amount is reasonably estimable. Being named as a potentially responsible party often triggers this assessment.
questions.tip: Environmental: accrue when probable and estimable.

questions.question: Guarantees of the indebtedness of others must be disclosed:

options.B: Regardless of the probability of loss
options.C: Only if the guarantee is in writing

questions.explanation: Certain guarantees require disclosure regardless of the likelihood of making payments, including guarantees of indebtedness, performance guarantees, and indemnification agreements.
questions.tip: Guarantees: disclose even if remote.

questions.question: An asset retirement obligation should be recognized:

options.B: At fair value when a legal obligation exists and can be reasonably estimated
options.C: Only if the obligation is certain
options.D: At the book value of the related asset

questions.explanation: Asset retirement obligations are recognized at fair value in the period when a legal obligation is incurred, if a reasonable estimate can be made. The liability is initially measured at fair value.
questions.tip: ARO: recognize at fair value when legal obligation arises.

questions.question: An expected insurance recovery related to a recognized loss contingency is:

options.B: Recognized separately when recovery is probable
options.D: Recorded at the same time as the loss

questions.explanation: Expected insurance recoveries are recognized as assets separately from the loss when recovery is probable. The recovery cannot be netted against the liability.
questions.tip: Insurance recovery: separate asset when probable.

questions.question: If events after the balance sheet date raise substantial doubt about going concern:

options.B: The entity should evaluate and disclose management's plans and the conditions
options.C: The financial statements must be prepared on a liquidation basis
options.D: Only auditors need to evaluate this

questions.explanation: If conditions or events raise substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern, management must evaluate whether their plans alleviate doubt and make appropriate disclosures.
questions.tip: Going concern doubt: evaluate plans, disclose conditions.

questions.question: A company self-insures for certain risks. How should uninsured losses be handled?

options.A: Accrue an estimated amount for all possible future losses
options.B: Accrue only for losses that have been incurred (claims reported or estimable)
options.C: No accrual is permitted for self-insured risks

questions.explanation: Self-insurance accruals are made only for losses that have been incurred by the balance sheet date. Future losses from self-insurance cannot be accrued in advance.
questions.tip: Self-insurance: accrue only for incurred losses.

questions.question: A cash dividend declared after the balance sheet date but before financial statement issuance is:

options.A: Accrued as a liability at year-end
options.B: Not recorded as a liability; may be disclosed
options.C: Recorded as a reduction of retained earnings at year-end

questions.explanation: Dividends declared after year-end are not a liability at the balance sheet date because no obligation existed. Disclosure of the subsequent declaration may be appropriate.
questions.tip: Post-year-end dividend declaration: disclose only.

questions.question: For unasserted claims (potential claims where no lawsuit has yet been filed), disclosure is required if:

options.B: It is probable a claim will be asserted and a reasonable possibility of unfavorable outcome exists
options.C: Management is aware of any potential issue
options.D: Never, since no claim has been made

questions.explanation: Unasserted claims require disclosure when: (1) it's probable the claim will be asserted and (2) there's a reasonable possibility of an unfavorable outcome.
questions.tip: Unasserted claims: probable assertion + reasonably possible loss.

questions.question: A significant business acquisition completed after year-end but before financial statement issuance is:

options.A: Recorded in the current year financial statements
options.B: A nonrecognized subsequent event requiring disclosure
options.D: Recorded at fair value in current year

questions.explanation: A business acquisition after year-end is a nonrecognized (Type 2) subsequent event because it represents a new condition arising after year-end. It requires disclosure if material.
questions.tip: Post-year acquisition: Type 2 = disclose only.

questions.question: A liability for one-time employee termination benefits under a restructuring plan is recognized when:

options.B: The plan is communicated to employees and meets other recognition criteria

questions.explanation: One-time termination benefits are recognized when the plan is communicated to affected employees and it's probable benefits will be paid and the amount is estimable.
questions.tip: Termination benefits: recognize when communicated to employees.
